Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story:
I sat at my workbench, blueprints spread out before me, the scent of fresh pine lingering in the air. Tomorrow, I’d be leading the assembly of a custom cabinet set—a big step in my carpentry career. But as I traced the lines on the drawings, a term jumped out at me: “dado joint.” I’d heard it before, but suddenly, I wasn’t sure I understood it fully. As a mentee, I was supposed to reach out to my mentor with any questions, no matter how small. But this didn’t feel urgent; I could probably figure it out with a quick search or by piecing together what I already knew.

Still, the expectation nagged at me. My mentor always said, “Don’t let confusion fester—ask.” But as a carpenter, I was expected to be prepared, self-reliant, and ready to interpret technical documents on my own. I worried that asking about something so basic would make me seem unprepared for tomorrow’s project. My phone sat on the bench, my mentor’s number ready to dial. I stared at it, torn between reaching out and proving I could handle this on my own.
